Award.AwardTitle: How Binary Companion Stars Impact Stellar Rotational Evolution
Award.AbstractNarration:
Stephanie Douglas is awarded an NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Fellowship to conduct a program of research and education at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics. Douglas will observe hundreds of binary stars (stars that orbit each other) to measure their physical properties. This will allow a better understanding of how stars---and their effects on planets---change with time. Alongside this research, Douglas will provide astronomy research experiences to middle school students from socioeconomically disadvantaged backgrounds and to undergraduate students from groups underrepresented in science.

Douglas will study the relationship between a star's rotation period and the proximity of a companion. Observations of open clusters show that among stars of a given age, the rapid rotators tend to be binaries. This could be because of tidal effects acting over 0.01 - 10 billion years or interactions between the binary companion and the protoplanetary disk during the first 10 million years. Both effects would cause binary stars to rotate faster than single stars, thus affecting angular momentum evolution in the binary systems. Douglas will combine rotation periods and binary orbital parameters to explain why rapidly rotating stars tend to be binaries. Douglas will use photometry, spectroscopy, and light curves to identify candidate binaries as well as new radial velocity observations to measure orbits. These data will allow her to test how binary companions affect stellar rotation over time. For the educational component of her work, Douglas will develop inquiry-based activities to introduce middle school students to binary and exoplanet research. She will also advise undergraduate students from underrepresented backgrounds on projects related to binary and exoplanet research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of this project was to investigate the relationship between a star's rotation period and the proximity of a companion. This involved compiling rotation periods and multiplicity data for stars in open clusters. Rotation periods were measured for stars in open clusters, and large catalogs of radial velocity and imaging observations were compiled. One publication resulted from this award, focused on rotation in the Hyades and Praesepe open clusters, which are supposedly the same age. This paper demonstrated that, once confirmed or candidate binaries were removed from each cluster's dataset, Sun-like stars in the Hyades are clearly more evolved (rotating more slowly) than their Praesepe counterparts. The paper also demonstrated that lower-mass stars in the two clusters had\ve comparable rotation periods, likely due to mass-dependent differences in how angular momentum is transported in the stars' interiors. This shows how studies of stellar rotation can have significant impacts on our understanding of these stars as a whole, as long as the impact of binaries is taken into account. 

Unforseen circumstances in the third year of the project (bad weather and observatory closures due to the Covid-19 pandemic) prevented the completion of the binary catalogs being developed as part of this project. Nonetheless, this dataset will provide a significant baseline for future studies of binaries in open clusters, and will be published as soon as possible. 

 

The broader impact goal of the project wais to introduce students from underrepresented groups to binary and other stellar research, and to support their entrance into the academic workforce. The PI mentored two undergraduate students doing research the Banneker Institute summer program at the Center for Astrophysics | Harvard & Smithsonian. Through their programs and through one-on-one meetings with the PI, these students learned to analyze time-series spectroscopy data, make plots, use Python, write abstracts, and give presentations. These research experiences will help prepare them for graduate school and a future career in astronomy.  Both students have moved on to the next stage in their careers: one to a bridge program in physics and the other to a master's program in astronomy

The second component was to teach an inquiry-style lesson to students from underrepresented groups. In the first year, the PI developed a lesson on exoplanet transits for a local eighth grade class. When circumstances prevented a return to that school after year one, the PI lead a team to develop another inquiry-based lesson for summer students in the Banneker Institute. The goal of both lessons was to replicate aspects of authentic scientific research while helping students learn about astronomy topics. For example, during the six-hour lesson for Banneker students, participants learned the basics of stellar spectroscopy, asked questions about stellar spectra of different types, investigated these questions with support from the instructional team, and presented their results in a mini poster session.
